physdesc.label: Quantity
physdesc.extent: plus additions of 5.2 cubic feet (6 boxes) and 455 digital files (2 GB)

extref.corpname: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries, Archives Department

did.abstract: Records of the UW-Milwaukee Student Union, including annual reports, event files, news clippings, and publications of its various departments. The collection largely consists of programming folders, flyers, and videos documenting the activities sponsored by the Union and its programming departments (Sociocultural Programming, Art Gallery, Union Cinema, Gasthaus, and Distinguished Lecture Series). Also included are handbooks, guides, and other brochures introducing the union and its services, programming brochures and reports, and issues of the Union News (1964-1978) and the Preview (1979-2009). Materials describing the activities of the Union Theatre and Union Cinema, including festivals, are particularly well represented.

bioghist.p: The UW-Milwaukee Student Union opened in 1956 and was expanded and remodeled numerous times to accommodate a growing student population. The UW-Milwaukee Student Union is a cultural, social, and recreational center for the UWM community, housing an art gallery, bookstore, cinema, recreation center, craft centre, food service and dining areas, as well as meeting rooms and offices, including those of student organizations. The Union Policy Board is responsible for formulating and setting policy for the overall operation of the Union.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains a large amount of material relating to the administration of the Student Union, including materials related to building construction and governance, and annual reports from each of the main functional sub-departments of the Union. The bulk of the collection is comprised of materials from the programming departments, including annual programming notes, flyers and posters, correspondence with speakers, and in some cases audio or video recordings of events. Also included are press clippings relating to the Student Union gathered from a diverse selection of publications between 1948 and 2009.
The collection is arranged as eight series:

The General Files document those aspects of Union history not directly related to a particular programming unit, including files on units with no programming responsibility (such as the Bookstore). The Programming Yearbooks, which comprise core documentation for events held at the Union, contain publicity materials, event summaries, and budgets for events held by various Union departments. A large number of Annual Reports, covering the period 1981-1999, provide summaries of the year-long operations of the various Student Union departments, including summaries of events, budgets, and program evaluations and recommendations. The Union Surveys, ranging from 1988 to 2000, include raw data and prepared reports detailing the reaction of the student body to the various Union programming events. The clippings files, containing information on local media coverage of Union events, can be found in this subseries.

The Governance Files include records of committees and governing bodies responsible for setting policy for various units of the Union. The bulk of these records are from the Union Policy Board, a group comprised of students, faculty, and staff that helps set policies on issues of interest to Union users. Also included are records of smaller committees that set policy on specialized issues, such as the Arts Board and the Activities Board.

The Sociocultural Programming Files primarily consist of publicity documents, planning notes, budgets, and correspondence. The files include information on a number of regular events held by the department, including Interfest and the Multicultural Breakfast. Other files deal with speakers, panel discussions, special events, and forums held by the Sociocultural Programming Department during this time, including speakers Albin Seaborg and Toni Morrison, as well as special programs such as African Market Days and the Ebony Ball. Most of the videos in the Student Union collection were produced by Sociocultural Programming, and include recordings of lectures from figures such as Angela Davis and Wilma Mankiller, as well as more general programs such as The Midwest Affirmative Action Debate and Bags, Brooms, Bottles, and Bedcovers: HooDoo Folk Beliefs in Fine Arts.

The Distinguished Lecture Series Files includes materials related to speakers on issues of national significance, such as Cornel West, Harry Wu, Nikki Giovanni, Naomi Wolf, and Juan Williams. Materials in this series are primarily comprised of correspondence with speakers, promotional material for events, and occasionally feedback on events from participants. The series includes videos for some programs.

The Union Art Gallery Files and Gasthaus Entertainment Series Files are comprised almost exclusively of promotional material for events and exhibits. The Union Cinema Files include promotional materials of film screenings and some named film series, such as the Asian Film Festival, the Festival of Films in French, the Latin American Film Series, and the Milwaukee LGBT Film/Video Festival.

The Publications series consists of publications by Union departments. The most comprehensive of these is Preview, the monthly event calendar for the Union, which describes all scheduled programming events in the Union beginning in 1979. There are other, smaller publications that may also be of interest, including student handbooks, Craft Centre brochures, and the annual art calendar released by the UWM Bookstore.

arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into the following series and subseries:

Files in series 1-4 and Series 8 are arranged alphabetically by folder heading. Files in series 5-7 are arranged chronologically, and thereunder alphabetically. Videos are housed separately from paper files.
Files in boxes 48-50 were segregated for reasons of size or format, but are otherwise arranged according to the series to which they belong.
The collection contains one additional accession.

otherfindaid.p: A spreadsheet with file-level information on the electronic records is available in the Archives department. The spreadsheet contains information on original file name, file size, date and time of creation of original file, duration (where applicable) and software used to create the file. Additional technical metadata is available in the Archives; see an archivist for more information.

accessrestrict.p: Electronic records must be viewed in the Archives. See an archivist for more information.
There are no access restrictions on the materials, and the collection is open to all members of the public in accordance with state law.

userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming with the laws of libel, privacy, and copyright which may be involved in the use of this collection (Wisconsin Statutes 19.21-19.39).

acqinfo.p: Most of the publications in the original collection appear to have been collected by Archives staff. Other materials were transferred to the Archives prior to 1989. Fran Ginter periodically transferred Sociocultural Programming materials to the Archives between 1991 and 1995. Union staff transferred accession 2008-019 in September 2008, accession 2010-032 in November 2010, accession 2011-006 in August 2011, accession 2011-019 in November 2011, accession 2011-025 in December 2011, accession 2011-046 in May 2012, and accession 2011-047 in June 2012. Accession 2015-008 was transferred to the Archives in September 2015.

processinfo.p: Christel T. Maass processed the original collection in August 1995. Jeremy Brett added several files in February 2007. Allen Ramsey added accession 2008-019 to the collection in April 2009 (Brad Houston supervised). Shukrani Gray processed accession 2010-032 in February 2011 (Brad Houston supervised). Michael Doylen added Milwaukee LGBT Film/Video Festival materials in May 2012. Charles Welborn processed additional material in August 2012. In fall 2013 and winter 2014 staff reprocessed the entire collection and added accessions 2011-006, 2011-019, 2011-025, 2011-046, and 2011-047. Brad Houston added information about accession 2015-008 in October 2015. Phyllis Reske processed some additional records in July 2016 (Brad Houston supervised). Christel Maass added remaining materials from accession 2011-046 to the collection in November 2016.

phystech.p: As of December 13, 2013, all electronic files were accessible on a Intel Core 2 Duo CPU (2.33 GHz, 1.95 GB RAM) running Windows XP Professional Version 2002, with Service Pack 3. Windows Media Player was used to access the files.
The collection contains records in the following formats:

processinfo.head: Preservation Information
processinfo.p: AVI files were ripped from their original DVD formats by Brad Houston in November 2013 and saved using the H.264 codec. Freemake Video Converter 4.0.4 was used to rip and convert the files.

did.unittitle: Guillermoprieto, Alma, Columbia: The Unbroken War

bioghist.p: The first annual gay and lesbian film festival in Milwaukee was organized by the Lavender Commitment student organization at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee in January 1983. It wasn't the first time that gay and lesbian films were shown at UWM--the Gay Peoples Union student organization had screened films in the Union in 1971, and the Gay & Lesbian Community organization had shown films in 1982 as part of UWM's Gay Day--but 1983 was the first time that screenings were billed as an annual event. The Lavender Commitment held six annual festivals from 1983 to 1988. In 1992 Great Lakes Film & Video (GLFV), with significant financial support from the Cream City Foundation, began its own LGBT film and video series. This series ran until 1996, in which year there was both a spring and fall festival. In 1996, GLFV became a programming arm of UWM's School of Fine Arts, where the festival currently resides.

scopecontent.p: This series includes promotional materials of the Milwaukee LGBT Film/Video Festival, as well as its precedecessors, the Lavender Commitment student organization from 1983 through 1988 and Great Lakes Film & Video Festival from 1992 through 1996.

relatedmaterial.p: Further information about the Lavender Commitment student organization may be found in the UW-Milwaukee Office of the Dean of Student Records (UWM Archival Collection 48), and information about the Great Lakes Film & Video Festival in the Cream City Foundation Records (UWM Manuscript Collection 205). Researchers should also consult Union Theatre programming materials elsewhere in this collection.

did.unittitle: Preview: A Complete Guide to the UWM Union, 1979-1984
Preview: This Month in the UWM Union, 1979-1981

did.abstract: Photographs and publicity materials for events held in the Student Union. Most of the content is from the programming departments in the union, in particular Sociocultural Programming, the Union Theater, and the Union Art Gallery. In many cases the photographs correspond to events in the existing collection; the photos are internal to the Union and not duplicative of material in Photo Services. The electronic files also include annual reports for the Union and its constituent departments from 2008-2015, as well as digital images of events in the Student Arts and Crafts Center and Union Art Gallery.
